context: It would appear that <a1_0><b4_0>living organisms<b4_0/><a1_0/> are remarkably inefficient (in the physical sense) in their use of the energy they receive (chemical energy or radiation), and it is true that most real machines manage higher efficiencies. In growing organisms the energy that is converted to heat serves a vital purpose, as it allows the organism tissue to be highly ordered with regard to the molecules it is built from. <a0_0>The <b3_0>second law of thermodynamics<b3_0/><a0_0/> states that energy (and matter) tends to become more evenly spread out across the universe: to concentrate energy (or matter) in one specific place, it is necessary to spread out a greater amount of energy (as heat) across the remainder of the universe ("the surroundings").[note 3] Simpler organisms can achieve higher energy efficiencies than more complex ones, but the complex organisms can occupy <a2_0><b7_0>ecological niches<b7_0/><a2_0/> that are not available to their simpler brethren. The conversion of a portion of the chemical energy to heat at each step in a <b5_0>metabolic pathway<b5_0/> is the physical reason behind the pyramid of biomass observed in <b6_0>ecology<b6_0/>: to take just the first step in the food chain, of the estimated 124.7 Pg/a of carbon that is fixed by photosynthesis, 64.3 Pg/a (52%) are used for the metabolism of green plants, i.e. reconverted into carbon dioxide and heat.
